qas.question: Who formulated the idea of clonal selection theory of immunity?
What are two examples of nonself entities in accordance with Frank Burnet's theory?
What is the complex "two-signal" activation of T cells referred to?
What other scientist influence Frank Burnet when he was formulating his theory of immunity?
What theory did Niels Jerne formulate?
Who did Frank Burnet inspire with a suggestion?
What theory of immunity is no longer influential?

plausible_answers.text: theory of how an immune response is triggered according to the self/nonself distinction

qas.question: What did Jerne develop on the basis of CST?
What did Frank Burnet formulate before the 1950s?

context: In the mid-1950s, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>Frank Burnet<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, inspired by a suggestion made by <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b5_0>Niels Jerne<b5_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, formulated the <b4_0><b8_0>clonal selection theory<b8_0/><b4_0/> (CST) of immunity. On the basis of CST, Burnet developed a <b7_0>theory of how an immune response is triggered according to the self/nonself distinction<b7_0/>: "self" constituents (constituents of the body) do not trigger destructive immune responses, while "nonself" entities (<a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>pathogens, an allograft<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>) trigger a destructive immune response. The theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries regarding <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>histocompatibility<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> or the complex "two-signal" activation of T cells. The <b6_0>self/nonself theory<b6_0/> of immunity and the self/nonself vocabulary have been criticized, but remain very influential.
